video_title: Tool for Better Eyesight & Eye Health | Dr. Jeff Goldberg & Dr. Andrew Huberman

environmental conditions

in their teen years
in terms of how their
visual system wires up,

scientific literature,
clinical studies,
clinical trials, excuse me, or otherwise

visual environment consists of?
Yeah, yeah.
That's a great question and actually,

It's more common
in Asian populations.
You know, it's called
an epidemic in China.
In California, we have
a lot of Asian heritage

Now what's interesting

the assumption, some of the data

path of thinking like,
"Gosh, the more you spend
at near activities,"
and these are mouse model

human cohort studies,
you know, figuring out,

nearsighted are they?"

those sort of, you know,
preteen and even into the teen years,

When they've now studied
and asked the kids
instead of just how much near

how much time are you spending

we've actually already seen
the first couple randomized
controlled trials

be often much more indoor time,

over a couple of years

are progressing in their
nearsightedness less.

as the kids who are
spending more time indoors.
And there's some pretty good biology
that's getting worked out,
going back to animal models more

in the retina inside the eye.

you may want to be telling your kid like,
"Okay, yeah, I want
you to read that book,"
or, you know, if your
kid's playing on the phone

they're allowed that time.
"Okay, you can have that time,

Are there any thresholds
for the amount of time
that one would suggest
their child be outdoors
to get that full-spectrum light?
It's a great question.

where we just ask people
what are they doing,

a little bit of what we would call
a dose-dependent response.
Maybe the more time
outdoors might be better.
We don't know if there's an upper limit.
Like, gosh, if you go
over two or three hours,
there's no additional benefit.
Talk about that in cohort studies.
The real gold standard

or a control group that's
not getting the intervention.
That's our highest level of
evidence for clinical evidence,
for any of this kind of science,
when we're talking about humans

question is to randomize kids,
to telling this group of kids,

tell this group of kids, "We

zero and one or two hours

is five hours better?

of course a child could be

If you're indoors,

Yeah, yeah.
So, it's,

randomized clinical trial for this.
